name: Chuck Schuldiner
description: '''Charles Michael Schuldiner''' ({{IPAc-en|ʃ|u:|l|'|d|i:|n|@r|}}; May 13, 1967 – December 13, 2001) was an American musician. He cofounded the pioneering [[Florida death metal]] band [[Death (metal band)|Death]] in 1983, in which he was the guitarist, primary songwriter and only continuous member until his death in 2001. He became the lead vocalist in 1985 after original drummer and vocalist [[Kam Lee]] left the band. His obituary in the January 5, 2002, issue of ''[[Kerrang!]]'' described him as "one of the most significant figures in the history of metal." Schuldiner was ranked No. 10 in [[Joel McIver]]'s book ''The 100 Greatest Metal Guitarists'' in 2009{{cn|date=July 2025}} and No. 20 in March 2004 ''[[Guitar World]]''{{'}}s "The 100 Greatest Metal Guitarists". In 1987, Schuldiner founded the publishing company Mutilation Music, affiliated with performance rights organization [[Broadcast Music Incorporated|BMI]]. Schuldiner died in 2001 of a [[brain tumor]].
